qas.question: Who split the leadership roles in the Qing dynasty?
Where did the Qing find their officials?
How many ranks were there in civil service in the Qing dynasty?

context: The early Qing emperors adopted the bureaucratic structures and institutions from the preceding Ming dynasty but split rule between <a0_0>Han Chinese and Manchus<a0_0/>, with some positions also given to Mongols. Like previous dynasties, the Qing recruited officials via the <a1_0>imperial examination system<a1_0/>, until the system was abolished in 1905. The Qing divided the positions into civil and military positions, each having <a2_0>nine<a2_0/> grades or ranks, each subdivided into a and b categories. Civil appointments ranged from attendant to the emperor or a Grand Secretary in the Forbidden City (highest) to being a prefectural tax collector, deputy jail warden, deputy police commissioner or tax examiner. Military appointments ranged from being a field marshal or chamberlain of the imperial bodyguard to a third class sergeant, corporal or a first or second class private.
